div.span: hahaha oh man if he is. the thing is, i got some bad news to
well, apparently j told k he was concerned about my performance during the stack ui madness
"Just frustration that it wasn't going smoother, faster - but he's realizing NOW that those concerns were generated and exacerbated by Griffin."

"Josh did say that he did have some concerns about your performance during the hellish Stack UI days of yore, but he's had ZERO concerns since I've come back, which he figures is due to your performance being seen entirely through the Griffin filter during that time and therefore incredibly unfair. "
" He reiterated that his primary concern is that you're learning and growing, which I think is great."
So he's stoked again with engineering and your role and just wants to make sure that you have the support you need to move forward.

div.span: "We mostly talked about Griffin. Process and CSS aside, something's going to change next week in regards to G. If he remains, then process and CSS will be part of the next conversation, in which we figure out how he participates in a functioning team.
gaaah i don't know what to say!

and the WHOLE thing was about g

but in the end couldn't help myself and said
that if he does end up leaving
and i could help with that while you look for someone

div.span: no i didn't feel too ok about it
like, how the hell have they not figured it out yet

that it doesn't make any sense to keep him on anymore
but aside from that he said all the things that i was planning to hint at
and the reason for g being here sitll
is because j was up till now sort of more interested in the design part of this company
and so didn't see waht was happening on our side of things
and now that he's around more he sees it
and he thinks , he says, it's unacceptable

but right now i don't really
heeeyyyyyy just don't hate me for what i said

div.span: but that was definitely not hinting
that was — telling me everything i felt

div.span: oh hey remember when your parents had dinner with us
and i was talking to your dad about mario savio

There is a time when the operation of the machine becomes so odious, makes you so sick at heart, that you can't take part. You can't even passively take part! And you've got to put your bodies upon the gears and upon the wheels, upon the levers, upon all the apparatus, and you've got to make it stop! And you've got to indicate to the people who run it, to the people who own it — that unless you're free, the machine will be prevented from working at all!
